LayoutNode.Content: World Europe US Americas Asia Australia Middle East Africa Inequality Cities Global development Donald Trump Donald Trump's threat to Kim Jong-un: make a deal or suffer samefate as Gaddafi Asked about ‘Libya model’, Trump says: ‘That model … was total decimation. That model would take place if we don’t make a deal’
LayoutNode.SRC:
World Europe US Americas Asia Australia Middle East Africa Inequality Cities Global development Donald Trump

Donald Trump's threat to Kim Jong-un: make a deal or suffer same fate as Gaddafi

Asked about ‘Libya model’, Trump says: ‘That model … was total decimation. That model would take place if we don’t make a deal’

LayoutNode.Content: Julian Borger in Washington Fri 18 May 2018 07.01 BST
LayoutNode.SRC: Julian Borger in WashingtonFri 18 May 2018 07.01 BST

LayoutNode.Content: This article is over 4 months old
LayoutNode.SRC: This article is over 4 months old

LayoutNode.Content: Trump at the White House on Wednesday. The ‘Libya model’ John Bolton was referring to was Gaddafi’s agreement to surrender his nuclear weapons in 2003.Photograph: Evan Vucci/AP
Donald Trump has threatened Kim Jong-un with the same fate as Muammar Gaddafi if the North Korean leader “doesn’t make a deal” on his nuclear weapons programme.
LayoutNode.SRC: Donald Trump has threatened Kim Jong-un with the same fate as Muammar Gaddafi if the North Korean leader “doesn’t make a deal” on his nuclear weaponsprogramme.

LayoutNode.Content: The US president issued the threat at the White House when he was asked about the recent suggestion by his national security adviser, John Bolton, that the “Libyan model” be a template for dealing with North Korea at a summit between Trump and Kim planned for 12 June in Singapore.
LayoutNode.SRC: The US president issued the threat at the White House when he was asked about the recent suggestion by his national security adviser, John Bolton, that the“Libyan model” be a template for dealing with North Korea at a summit between Trump and Kim planned for 12 June in Singapore.

LayoutNode.Content: The model Bolton was referring to was Gaddafi’s agreement in December 2003 to surrender his embryonic nuclear weapons programme, which included allowinghis uranium centrifuges to be shipped out to the US.
LayoutNode.SRC: The model Bolton was referring to was Gaddafi’s agreement in December 2003 to surrender his embryonic nuclear weapons programme, which included allowing his uranium centrifuges to be shipped out to the US.

LayoutNode.Content: Sign up to receive the top US stories every morning
LayoutNode.SRC: <figcaption class="caption caption--img"> Sign up to receive the top US stories every morning </figcaption>

LayoutNode.Content: But Trump appeared to be unaware of that agreement, and interpreted the “Libyan model” to mean the 2011 Nato intervention in Libya in support of an insurrection, which ultimately led to Gaddafi’s murder at the hands of rebels in Tripoli.
LayoutNode.SRC: But Trump appeared to be unaware of that agreement, and interpreted the “Libyan model” to mean the 2011 Nato intervention in Libya in support of aninsurrection, which ultimately led to Gaddafi’s murder at the hands of rebels in Tripoli.

LayoutNode.Content: “The model, if you look at that model with Gaddafi, that was a total decimation. We went in there to beat him. Now that model would take place if we don’t make a deal, most likely. But if we make a deal, I think Kim Jong-un is going to be very, very happy,” Trump said, suggesting that the regime’s survival could be assured if Kim agreed to disarm.
LayoutNode.SRC: “The model, if you look at that model with Gaddafi, that was a total decimation. We went in there to beat him. Now that model would take place if we don’t make adeal, most likely. But if we make a deal, I think Kim Jong-un is going to be very, very happy,” Trump said, suggesting that the regime’s survival could be assuredif Kim agreed to disarm.

LayoutNode.Content: “This with Kim Jong-un would be something where he would be there. He would be running his country. His country would be very rich,” the president said.
LayoutNode.SRC: “This with Kim Jong-un would be something where he would be there. He would be running his country. His country would be very rich,” the president said.

LayoutNode.Content: “We’re willing to do a lot, and he’s willing … to do a lot also, and I think we’ll actually have a good relationship, assuming we have the meeting and assumingsomething comes of it. And he’ll get protections that will be very strong.”
LayoutNode.SRC: “We’re willing to do a lot, and he’s willing … to do a lot also, and I think we’ll actually have a good relationship, assuming we have the meeting and assuming something comes of it. And he’ll get protections that will be very strong.”

LayoutNode.Content: Asked whether his comments meant that he disagreed with his national security adviser, the third of his administration , the president said: “I think when John Bolton made that statement, he was talking about if we are going to be having a problem, because we cannot let that country have nukes. We just can’t do it.”
LayoutNode.SRC: Asked whether his comments meant that he disagreed with his national security adviser, the third of his administration, the president said: “I think when JohnBolton made that statement, he was talking about if we are going to be having a problem, because we cannot let that country have nukes. We just can’t do it.”

LayoutNode.Content: Joel Wit, a former US negotiator who is now a senior fellow at the US-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins University, said: “This is probably the wrong time to bemaking threats, three weeks before the summit.”
LayoutNode.SRC: Joel Wit, a former US negotiator who is now a senior fellow at the US-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins University, said: “This is probably the wrong time to bemaking threats, three weeks before the summit.”

LayoutNode.Content: The inflammatory comments come at a time when the June meeting is in doubt. The regime in Pyongyang reacted strongly against statements by Bolton over the weekend, who insisted North Korea would have to dismantle its nuclear arsenal completely and immediately. A senior official said on Wednesday that Kim would not take part in a summit with such “one-sided” goals.
LayoutNode.SRC: The inflammatory comments come at a time when the June meeting is in doubt. The regime in Pyongyang reacted strongly against statements by Bolton over theweekend, who insisted North Korea would have to dismantle its nuclear arsenal completely and immediately. A senior official said on Wednesday that Kim wouldnot take part in a summit with such “one-sided” goals.

LayoutNode.Content: Trump in a White House meeting with Mike Pompeo (middle), JohnBolton, (far right) and the Nato chief Jens Stoltenberg (far left).Photograph: Pool/Getty Images
FacebookTwitterPinterest
LayoutNode.SRC: Facebook Twitter Pinterest

LayoutNode.Content: Pyongyang has also complained about joint military exercises being conducted by US and South Korean forces. The regime’s mission to the United Nations issued a statement on Thursday claiming that nuclear-capable B-52 bombers and F-22 fighter planes were taking part in the exercises. He described it as “an extremely provocative and ill-boding act”.
LayoutNode.SRC: Pyongyang has also complained about joint military exercises being conducted by US and South Korean forces. The regime’s mission to the United Nations issued a statement on Thursday claiming that nuclear-capable B-52 bombers and F-22 fighter planes were taking part in the exercises. He described it as “an extremelyprovocative and ill-boding act”.

LayoutNode.Content: However, Trump said that despite Pyongyang’s threats to call off the summit, “they’ve been negotiating like nothing happened”.
LayoutNode.SRC: However, Trump said that despite Pyongyang’s threats to call off the summit, “they’ve been negotiating like nothing happened”.

LayoutNode.Content: The state department spokeswoman, Heather Nauert, said: “We are continuing to push ahead and plan our preparations. Those continue at this time for ameeting between the president and Kim Jong-un in June.”
LayoutNode.SRC: The state department spokeswoman, Heather Nauert, said: “We are continuing to push ahead and plan our preparations. Those continue at this time for a meeting between the president and Kim Jong-un in June.”

LayoutNode.Content: Trump: 'We'll see' if North Korea summit is on after Kim's threat to cancel Read more At a meeting in Tokyo on Tuesday, a senior state department official suggested that a substantial but partial disarmament by North Korea might be acceptable as the first stage of a deal with North Korea .
LayoutNode.SRC:
Trump: 'We'll see' if North Korea summit is on after Kim's threat to cancel

Read more
At a meeting in Tokyo on Tuesday, a senior state department official suggested that a substantial but partial disarmament by North Korea might be acceptable asthe first stage of a deal with North Korea.

LayoutNode.Content: Speaking to a meeting of business executives in Tokyo organised by the Wall Street Journal , Susan Thornton, the acting assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific Affairs, said that in Kim’s conversations with South Korean officials, he had said “there will be a big downpayment, a big up-front demonstration of his intention” to dismantle the North Korean nuclear weapons programme completely.
LayoutNode.SRC: Speaking to a meeting of business executives in Tokyo organised by the Wall Street Journal, Susan Thornton, the acting assistant secretary of state for East Asiaand Pacific Affairs, said that in Kim’s conversations with South Korean officials, he had said “there will be a big downpayment, a big up-front demonstration of hisintention” to dismantle the North Korean nuclear weapons programme completely.

LayoutNode.Content: “The question is: what could be front-loaded in a process that’s inevitably going to go on for some time? And then what would be acceptable to the North Koreanside in return for that front-loading?” Thornton said.
LayoutNode.SRC: “The question is: what could be front-loaded in a process that’s inevitably going to go on for some time? And then what would be acceptable to the North Korean side in return for that front-loading?” Thornton said.

LayoutNode.Content: It was unclear whether Thornton’s remarks had been coordinated with Bolton, who has suggested that North Korea would have to dismantle its nuclear weaponscompletely before receiving any benefits.
LayoutNode.SRC: It was unclear whether Thornton’s remarks had been coordinated with Bolton, who has suggested that North Korea would have to dismantle its nuclear weapons completely before receiving any benefits.

LayoutNode.Content: Suzanne DiMaggio, a senior fellow at the New America thinktank who has played a lead role in back-channel talks with North Korea, said: “Given the high degreeof distrust between Pyongyang and Washington, anything short of a phased approach with confidence measures built in along the way is pure fantasy.”
LayoutNode.SRC: Suzanne DiMaggio, a senior fellow at the New America thinktank who has played a lead role in back-channel talks with North Korea, said: “Given the high degree of distrust between Pyongyang and Washington, anything short of a phased approach with confidence measures built in along the way is pure fantasy.”
